newsitem.title: USA: US Plains cattle post-holiday trade quiet-feedlots.
newsitem.headline: US Plains cattle post-holiday trade quiet-feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets early Monday were inactive as packers evaluated needs and surveyed feedlot inventories following the three-day Independence Day holiday weekend, feedlot sources said.

Favorable weather across the nation's midsection and widespread retail beef promotions last week could spark retail fill-in buying this week, which was seen keeping fed cattle prices steady at $63.00 per cwt, several feedlot sources said.
"Beef movement will be the key to this market the next three to four weeks and it looks like we should have had great movement over the weekend," a Panhandle feedlot manager said.
Packer bids were expected to surface at $61.00 to $62.00 per cwt but were not expected to be very widespread, sources said. Owners were pricing cattle at $63.00 to $65.00.
The bulk of last week's cattle sales in the central and southern Plains were at $63.00 on Tuesday, with a few heifers at $62.00 in Kansas on Wednesday.

Attempts at maintaining steady prices this week could be blunted by outlooks for increased cattle supplies this month, sources said. Most feedlots were said to be near current, with a few cattle carried over from last week.
Early estimates for this week's showlists were steady to larger, compared with last week, the sources said.
